SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to Senator Harradine's amendment to the Export Market Development Grants Amendment Bill I would like to support his valid concern over the possible damage to Australia's national image of having the Government subsidise the export of X-rated videos. I would also like to comment on the fact that the amendment expresses concern only over the export of videos of a sexually explicit nature. The point is that the debate is limited to films of a sexual nature. I am concerned about the need for the creation of a category of extreme violence on its own. The current category system does not address this specific concern.

SPEECH.PARA: To exemplify my concerns and the confusion which exists in the community over this, an Australian film called Blood Moon was released around Australia during the April school holidays this year. The film had a mature audience classification, which would allow children of 15 years plus to view it. This Australian made production involved a huge promotional exercise. The film's poster depicted a naked man with a weapon looking at pretty schoolgirls all in a row. The poster caused great public controversy in Western Australia, and I imagine in other parts of Australia as well. The plot of the film involved a male schoolteacher strangling pretty schoolgirls all in a row-presumably a pun on the limerick which ends `and then there were none'-with barbed wire, cutting off their fingers and ripping out their eyes.

Part of the film's promotional gimmickry was a break in the middle of the program for viewers to go and get their money back if they were too afraid to continue watching the film or if it was not exciting or violent enough. Presumably the promoters hoped they would attract a lot of young viewers to the box office. I think they were successful in doing that.

The point is that this scenario is extremely distasteful to many Australians and the Government has a responsibility to look into the issue of violent films as well as those of a sexual nature. How could such a violent, ghastly film rate only an M classification? We urgently need a reclassification to sort out the confusion which exists between violence of all kinds and non-violent erotica.

I support many of Senator Coulter's comments on that line. This is why in the past I have not voted in support of Senator Harradine's various amendments on this issue and why I did not support Senator Walters' private member's Bill-Regulation of Video Material Bill 1988-on this issue. The difference now is that in this situation taxpayers' money could be used to subsidise this unsavoury industry, which I do not support. This is not a question of banning material which individuals should have a choice about, but it is a matter of using taxpayers' money to subsidise the promotion of pornography, which is in many cases especially degrading to women. I feel that to try to build a reputation for exporting such films is detrimental to our nation.

In the same way, I also oppose the use of taxpayers' money for promotion of weapons sales overseas. That certainly is a case of exporting violence if ever there was one. I support what Senator Coulter said on that matter. I am even more concerned about the Government's promotion, in the taxpayers' name, of exporting weapons which are used for repressing citizens of neighbouring countries, in many cases resulting in their deaths. As was said yesterday in this debate, a long list of nasties which attract government subsidy at the moment could be drawn up. Many of us would prefer not to subsidise many of these industries which we find distasteful, especially where violence is concerned. I look forward to a later opportunity to deal with those issues, as Senator Coulter has suggested.

To return to the matter immediately before the Committee, I wanted to put on record my reasons for supporting Senator Harradine's amendment today when I have not supported amendments he has put forward in the past.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have just listened to Senator Vallentine's and Senator Coulter's contributions. I do not understand Senator Vallentine's. She said that she did not support my private member's Bill-the Regulation of Video Material Bill 1988-`for that reason'. I presume she meant because of her approach to violent videos. But I am sure she must have realised that my Bill specifically dealt with extreme violence in videos. Indeed, my Bill had two aims only. One was to abolish those videos that showed extreme violence. I went to a great deal of trouble. I am sure Senator Vallentine can understand how difficult it is to identify extreme violence. Extreme violence in the eyes of one person is not exactly the same as extreme violence in the eyes of others.

SPEECH.PARA: I went to a considerable amount of trouble to have words framed, which were in line with the Joint Select Committee on Video Material, that specifically tried to get across to the Film Censorship Board at the time scenes that the Australian public would not want shown in videos. Yet, Senator Vallentine says that she would not support my Bill, because it did not condemn violence. I do not understand her. The other side of my Bill dealt with X-rated videos.

I refer to Senator Coulter's insulting and unsavoury attack on Senator Harradine. Frankly I was absolutely appalled that he would stand in this chamber, as a legislator and as a voter-knowing that that vote was essential at the time of my private member's Bill-and boast that he had never seen a pornographic video. Yet, he was prepared to vote on the issue. That is absolutely unbelievable. I cannot believe that a senator in this place would stand and say, `I know nothing about this; I have never seen one but I will cast my vote'. I cannot believe that anyone in this Parliament would stand up here and boast that he or she had no knowledge of pornographic videos yet accuse, denigrate and insult a particular senator who had been on the committee that his Party supported and who had been shown these videos, for his desire to have some of those videos banned. It is something I cannot understand.

Senator Vallentine, who is no longer in the chamber, said that she would like violence included in the amendment. It is extremely difficult to include in an amendment such as this videos that are extremely violent. It is very difficult to find the right frame of words. It is unbelievable that the video Senator Vallentine described in this chamber today passed the Film Censorship Board under the present guidelines.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you seen it, senator?

—I have not seen it. I did not know it was available. Had I known it was available then I certainly would have viewed it and asked the Film Censorship Board, in my capacity as a senator, how it could possibly pass such a film-if what Senator Vallentine has told us is right-under the present guidelines.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Button might well be interested in following that up for us. If Senator Vallentine's description of the mutilation of the schoolgirls in the film was as she stated, the Film Censorship Board could not possibly have passed it for any classification at all, far less an M classification. I agree entirely with her that that is far worse than anything I have heard of in this chamber or seen in some of the videos that our Committee members were shown by the Film Censorship Board that it believed were unclassifiable.
There is no doubt that we already have an export industry based on pornographic videos. I would like to quote from an article which appeared in the Melbourne Herald of 26 April 1989 which states:
Australia is poised to become a key centre for the distribution of X-rated videos to the lucrative Asian-Pacific market.

Canberra based distribution firms are already shipping large volumes of the controversial videos to New Zealand, taking advantage of the NZ Government's decision late last year to approve over-the-counter sales.
And the firms believe that the time is now right to exploit the Asian market, with signs that countries such as Japan and Korea are preparing to ease their censorship laws.

There is not doubt that Australia is now well in the market. Mr Lark has said very definitely that he will be applying for an export grant. He has said that he has many of the markets tied up already. If we believe that the image of Australia as the porn capital of Asia is appropriate we could allow this sort of thing to happen. But I am quite sure that the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) does not want that to occur. I ask the Minister to please take note of this: even if he does not mind X-rated videos being exported, I am sure that he would not want-I wish he would not yawn and pretend that he is not interested because this is terribly important-child pornography produced in this country and exported to New Zealand, the Asian markets and the European markets which Mr Lark tells us he has got sewn up.

Under the present situation-and I have approached the Australian Customs Service which has assured me that this is possible-Mr Lark could produce videos that are not permitted to be shown in Australia and that are quite illegal. If he were given an export grant he could use taxpayer's money to produce them and send them to the countries where no restrictions apply. It is quite possible for him to produce all of the videos that we prohibit in this country.

I can assure honourable senators that what I have just said is right. As I have already pointed out, I approached the Customs Service to verify it. I will wait for the Minister to give me his attention, Mr Temporary Chairman, because it is important that he listens to what I am saying. When we were debating this matter in the chamber last night, the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins) agreed with me that what I have just said is completely accurate. As I say, I checked with the Customs Service and I was assured that that was possible.

There should be some limit on what the Government is prepared to support with taxpayer's money in respect of exports. I would have imagined that the Government would have supported the amendment that was moved by Senator Harradine. As Senator Harradine indicated, he has picked up my particular concerns and, for clarity and ease, has included them in his amendment, thereby avoiding the need for me to amend his amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak in support of the amendment that has been moved by Senator Harradine not only on my own behalf, but also on behalf of the National Party senators in this chamber. I congratulate Senator Harradine on bringing forward this amendment to protect standards in this country. I believe it is good that he saw what was happening with the Export Market Development Grants Amendment Bill and brought forward this amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Last night Senator Collins, who was the Minister in the chamber, said that it was not an appropriate Bill to which to add an amendment of this nature. I just wonder when it will ever be appropriate to stop the export of X-rated videos from Canberra. The Legislative Assembly in Canberra tried to stop X-rated videos being made in and exported from Canberra but, unfortunately, it was not able to do anything about it. This is of concern to many people. One only needs to take note of the number of petitions that come into this place on the matter to realise that not just a certain number of senators in this chamber are concerned about it, but people right throughout Australia.

As Senator Harradine said, the purpose of this amendment is to ensure that export development grants are denied to hard-core pornography merchants so that they do not obtain taxpayers' money to exploit women. I agree with Senator Reid when she asked: why should taxpayers' funds be made available to support the export of this type of film and why should grants be made available for the promotion of X-rated films? I believe that the Government should not support this action at all.

I certainly agree with Senator Vallentine's idea, too, about the tremendous amount of violence in films these days, not just on videos, but also, unfortunately, on our television screens. It gives one the horrors to watch them. It is no wonder that so many acts of violence occur in our community by people, particularly young people, who see things on television and then decide to copy them. I think that is rather sad.

It is regrettable that Canberra is known as the porn capital of Australia. I think it would be much better to be known as the beautiful capital of Australia. I had an opportunity over lunch the other day to drive around and look at some of God's beautiful handiwork in the lovely colour of the trees around the city. We all realise that this building provides wonderful tourism opportunities-over a million tourists come through Parliament House each year-as does the Australian War Memorial, which honours the dead who fought for our country because they wanted to keep Australia free. I am sure that men and women in those days would not have thought that they would have to worry about standards becoming as low as they are in the country at present. I believe that the hard-core pornography being distributed from Canberra is certainly not doing anything to improve our values at present; in fact, I believe that it denigrates women.

The Labor Government believes that there has been tremendous discrimination against women. I believe that the Government has worked so hard to avoid discrimination against women that it is inclined to discriminate against men. That is my opinion on the matter. This Bill-and I heard Senator Lewis talking about it yesterday-provides many opportunities to help businesses, but we do not want it to help a business such as this that will assist somebody to export hard-core pornography. As a grandmother and mother, I am very concerned about the exploitation of women. That is why I want to place on record my feelings about this matter. Is it any wonder that we are worried about what happens to the future of our country? I want Australia to continue to be a country with good, wholesome Christian standards. That is why I want to put down my position on Senator Harradine's amendment. I place on record my support, and the National Party's support, for his amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps I can just indicate the Government's position relating to the amendments of Senator Harradine and Senator Walters. In fact, I understand that was done in some ways by Senator Collins last night when he indicated that the Government would look at these two amendments not without sympathy and attempt to deal with them when the substantial redrafting of the Bill is taking place. There has to be a Bill back here within the next six months.

SPEECH.PARA: I think the important point, which is one that has been made already by other senators, is how we quarantine this issue. After all, the export market development grants scheme is a scheme which, it is true, provides taxpayers' money to help exporters open up particular markets. It does not continue as an export subsidy; it is a scheme to help the opening up of export markets.

I do not want to see Australia become; in some of the ways which have been portrayed in other speeches; an exporter of X-rated videos or anything of that kind. I used the expression `quarantine'. There are all sorts of political influences imposed on this Parliament by various interest groups. Assuming a hypothetical situation, and Australia as a small exporter of tobacco, the anti-smoking lobby could come here the next time this legislation is before us and say it does not believe Australia should export tobacco. Australia is an exporter of beer and other alcoholic products. People could come here and say they do not want Australia to be an exporter of alcoholic products, therefore they do not think the export market development grants scheme should apply to the wine or beer industries or whatever.

TALK.START.PARA: —Woodchips.
—Woodchips, of course, is another good example which arouses some passions.
—It is easy. You could deal with them one at a time and the Parliament makes a decision.

—I have said in letters on this issue, which have been quoted by various honourable senators in letters to their constituents and so on, that the export market development grants scheme provides Austrade with a mechanism for administering grants. Mr Ferris, the Chairman of Austrade, in a response to Senator Reid put a very sensible position when he said that the Board does not favour the export of X-rated videos, but the rules have to be clear and they have to be equal in terms of all exporters.
—No, they do not. That is an assertion. It is his view.
—Well, that is Senator Newman's view. It is just a simple point of administrative law that as far as possible the rules are equal for everybody.
—So you cannot give any guarantee, then, that an application will not succeed in the meantime.

—I cannot give a guarantee because at the moment the production of X-rated videos in the Australian Capital Territory is not an unlawful activity. If it were to become an unlawful activity this debate would not arise. I would not mind if it did become an unlawful activity-and I am putting a personal view in saying that-but it is not an unlawful activity at the moment, and the export market development grants scheme must apply with equality to all lawful activities conducted in Australia, irrespective of particular prejudices or whatever.

SPEECH.PARA: I appreciate Senator Newman's passion on this issue. Other people have other passions about different things which might lead to much the same sorts of conclusions in relation to the export market development grants scheme. We are not as a government treating Senator Harradine's amendment lightly in any sense. We are saying that there have to be a whole series of amendments to the export market development grants legislation. That whole series of amendments will be brought back. I give an undertaking-I will discuss this further with Senator Harradine if he so wishes-that the issue raised in his amendment will be closely examined.

The point I am trying to make is that as far as possible one would like to quarantine that issue in terms of the export market development grants system against the possible encroachments of all the other things which are objectionable to certain people in this society. For example, Senator Vallentine has a view about this. Senator Coulter put a view about military equipment.

TALK.START.PARA: —He did not know what he was talking about. He had not seen them.

—I said that Senator Coulter put a view about military equipment. Senator Walters is conducting her usual mindless series of interjections and says that he had not seen them. That has nothing to do with what I am talking about or what Senator Coulter was talking about. I am in the unenviable position of not having seen any X-rated videos. I know that Senator Walters is an expert on the topic. Perhaps I have been deprived in some way during my life.
—It is a pity you don't because then you could make informed comments.

—Senator Walters says that my education is lacking. If I have some spare time and if I am really bored out of my mind I will get an X-rated video in order to satisfy Senator Walters that I am a well-educated person, but for no other reason.

SPEECH.PARA: I am saying to Senator Harradine, the mover of this motion, that this is inappropriate in the Government's view in the context of this legislation. This Bill is designed to extend the existing export market development grants scheme for six months to protect the interests of those who are currently making export plans and using the scheme until such time as new legislation has been brought forward. Perhaps by the time the new legislation has been brought forward this will be an unlawful activity in Australia. If it is not I undertake as the responsible Minister to closely examine his amendment. As I said, and as Senator Collins said last night, very careful and sympathetic consideration will be given to it. I otherwise commend the Bill to the Senate. I think we have had a lengthy debate on this and I recommend that it be adopted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition will support Senator Harradine's amendment. The attitude of the Opposition is along the lines indicated by Senator Button. We believe that the best solution to this problem would be to prohibit the production of these products in the Australian Capital Territory and throughout Australia. We think that there is massive support for that view right around this nation.

SPEECH.PARA: I, a little like Senator Button, am worried about the use of an amendment to the export market development grants scheme to achieve the object of this amendment. Nevertheless, like so many things that we deal with in this chamber it is a question of where to draw the line. That is what we are continually being faced with in this chamber. For example, if there were an industry in Australia producing poisonous gas and exporting it to some country which was threatening to use that gas on another country then clearly we would say that that is where another line ought to be drawn.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why would they want poison gas, Senator, unless they are going to use it?

—The point is that this industry already exists in Australia. It may very well be that it is not yet receiving the export market development grant which is available under this Bill. Nevertheless, by the time Senator Button comes back with his scheme, which he has been promising since about August of last year-and during the election campaign he told the people of Australia that the new scheme was, in effect, in existence-this industry may already have achieved an export market development grant. Senator Button and others would no doubt then argue that to pass an amendment along these lines would take away something that this organisation had already planned on and budgeted for in order to become established and, no doubt, would be to the detriment of the nation's income from export industries.
—You are getting silly now.

—That is the sort of argument that we hear in this chamber. The Opposition's view is that the line ought to be drawn above X-rated videos, and that is the way we will be voting. We believe that, as Senator Button has indicated, it might be better if the production of them were prohibited in Australia. Until it is, we will be doing our best to make sure that they do not get an export grant.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not going to speak after Senator Button. I was hoping that that would be the end of the debate. But several things have been said since that require some comment. Of course, a point that I have made frequently in the past is that under section 51 (i) and 51 (xx) of the Australian Constitution it is within the competence of the Commonwealth to legislate on all matters dealing with trade and commerce and corporations and, therefore, it is within the competence of the Commonwealth to ban the manufacture of this material. The Opposition has been extremely loath to use that section, claiming that States' rights are involved. During and just after the election former Senator Chaney and, I believe, the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) both indicated that the Opposition was considering changing its stance in relation to States' rights and the use of the corporation powers. If the Opposition is serious about this matter, let it use those powers and then it can proceed under that particular head of power in the Constitution.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me also pick up the point that Senator Walters was attempting to make. She claimed that I said I had not seen any of these videos. That is true. I said I had seen one `porno' film. That was sufficient. But I have read extensively in the area. Rather than simply react in an emotional way, I have read extensively on the effects of exposure of people to explicit sex and explicit violence. I ask whether Senator Walters is aware for instance, of the extensive work of Professor Bronsenbrenner in the United States. Professor Bronsenbrenner carried out quite objective work on the consequences of exposing people to violence and he did it in this way: he asked people to cooperate in an experiment in which those people were to help educate an unseen subject behind a screen. They were to do this by the subject being asked questions, and if the subject gave the wrong answer then these people were able to deliver electric shocks to the unseen subject behind the screen. In fact, the shocks were not really delivered, but they believed that they were being delivered.
Opposition senators interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There are too many interjections.

—There were a series of buttons and they could deliver shocks of varying degrees from one to 10 depending upon their desire to `train' this person behind the screen. People in this experiment were not told that they themselves, of course, were the subjects. What was done to these people is that before they were put into this experimental situation they were exposed to comics, cartoons, videos, film, writing and plays showing various degrees of violence, and the studies clearly showed that exposing people to violence-and not just below the age of 18-increased the level of violence with which these people behaved.

SPEECH.PARA: It may be that the Committee looked at this material, but it is clear that a lot of people in the community who respond in the way indicated by Senator Walters to explicit sex are not aware of this extensive research work in relation to exposing people to violence. The evidence is absolutely clear that exposing people to violence increases the level of violence in the community, and what I find disturbing about this repeated emphasis on sex is that the far greater damage being done to the community is through the exposure of people to violence rather than to sex. Overemphasis on the sexual aspects rather than the violent aspects seems to be ignored or downplayed, despite what Senator Walters has said about her private member's Bill, which I believe is doing, as Senator Vallentine has indicated, a great deal of damage to the Australian community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I feel like ignoring what has been said because it displays a degree of ignorance that is almost unbelievable. To almost accuse Senator Walters of not knowing the evidence that is available about violence when she and I and others spent six years on the question of violence and the mediation of the effects of video material, and to accuse me of having a voyeurism about sex, I think that Senator Coulter ought to stand up and withdraw the nonsense that he has spoken.

SPEECH.PARA: In fact, what Senator Coulter said was that I condone violence. Let me put that to rest right here and now. I go back to the report of the Joint Parliamentary Committee on X-rated Videos. There was very little about violence in the draft report of the Chairman of the Committee. Most of the material, including the analysis of the behavioural science evidence, was developed and written in my office. There was no help from the secretariat of the Committee at all on the area of violence. The report was studied and written in my office and, as a consequence, the majority of the Committee came down with stronger recommendations on violence than the minority of the Committee.

We recommended that there be a ban on films of relish to violence. Senator Coulter should try to find that in the report of the minority, who were supporting the continuance of the X-rated videos. We were the ones who were strong on violence. We were the ones who studied the evidence. We do not need Senator Coulter to tell us about how behavioural scientists go about their examination of this matter. We had six years of it.

Senator Coulter gets up here and says that he is not going to vote for this. He has not seen the material, but I suggest that he does not have to see it. He obviously has not read the report of the Joint Select Committee on Video Materials because he says of the X-rated material that sex between consenting adults is beautiful. Senator Coulter obviously has not read the description of this material in the Joint Select Committee report, which states:

Rather than treating women as free and responsible initiators of human activity, the material in this category, although not violent, treats women as sexual commodities to arouse the sexual desires of its target audience. Thus, sexual intercourse is typically depicted as a mechanical act, devoid of love or human consequences.

Does Senator Coulter describe that as beautiful? Does he describe as beautiful material where `women are often depicted as sexually malleable for the purposes of satisfying male sexual desires'? As the Committee said:
This is sometimes manifest by themes involving work place sexual favours. Women are frequently depicted-

I will not go on; it is all there, but the honourable senator obviously has not read it. Anal sex is beautiful, is it? That is in this material. Senator Coulter surely has not seen it, and I do not suggest anybody should see it, but I do suggest that people take the trouble and read the Joint Select Committee report on the matter so that they can understand the issues. I will not have any more of this nonsense suggesting that people are preoccupied with the sexual material and are unconcerned about the violence material. In fact, according to a number of behavioural scientists whose evidence was before us, the explicit sexual material engendered `a sexually callous and manipulative orientation towards women'. The evidence stated:
It mediates in the minds of the habitual viewer a perception of women as being highly promiscuous and therefore available.

It is interesting to note that at least four of the behavioural scientists whose work was subjected to the scrutiny of the Committee saw non-violent pornographic videos as being more harmful as to perception than the violent explicit pornography which has already been banned. Is AIDS-related high risk behaviour beautiful? I think Senator Coulter ought to think before he starts talking. He should realise that some of us who have been appointed by this Parliament to successive committees have had the onerous task of wading through the evidence on this material.

I did think of including the R-classification in the amendment because in R-classified films there is a great deal of violence-too much. I did think of including that, but it would have been almost impossible to isolate those areas of the R-classification which are the violent films. If somebody can come up with an idea on that, I will put it in, but I thought about it and I could not see how one could include it.

I am not going to say much more about that, but I do take up what Senator Button said. He said that Austrade has got to give a grant if an application is made and it is eligible, provided the undertaking is lawful. He also said that there is a problem with quarantining matters which people consider should not be eligible for an export market development grant. Frankly, Senator Button can do that overnight. He has the power himself. All he needs to do, as the responsible Minister, is draft an amendment to the Customs (Prohibited Exports) Regulations, and he can do that today. He can get that through Cabinet and wherever it has to go-to the Governor-General-and it can be done overnight.
If, as he says, he would rather this undertaking were illegal, he can sure make it illegal by amending the Customs (Prohibited Exports) Regulations, which would prohibit the export-

TALK.START.PARA: —It would make the export activity illegal, Senator, but not the activity here.
—That is right. Therefore, if it made the export illegal-and the Minister has the power to do this today-it obviously would not be eligible for an export grant.
—No.

—No, it would not be eligible for an export grant. He has it in his own hands. I suggest that an independent observer listening to him on the question of quarantining various areas in respect of the export market development grants scheme would say, `Heck, there are a lot of other things that are going to come down the track; it is going to be put in the too-hard basket and we are not going to get to it'.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact is, the chamber is faced with a problem. The problem is that the hard-core porn merchants have said they are after the grants. There is no guarantee, as the Minister said, that between now and when the matter is next considered by the Parliament, those grants will not be made. In fact, Lark has already had a small export development grant for some of his activities, and that has not come out in the debate. But he knows the ropes because he has made an application previously and has already been granted a small grant for some of his activities.

TALK.START.PARA: —What activities? You don't know.

—No, but I know that he has received a grant, although I am not sure for what. Therefore, he knows his way around. There is no guarantee that between now and when the matter finally comes up for a decision by this Parliament in November he will not get the very substantial grant he is after. That is the purpose of my amendment. I believe it is incumbent upon all senators to realise that people outside this Parliament do not want taxpayers' money to be used by these pornographers to prostitute the image of Australian women overseas.

—I understand that the provisions in this Bill will be of six months duration only. Therefore, I ask the Minister whether any amendment passed now by the Committee would also be of only six months duration. I ask this because, although I am sympathetic to the content of Senator Harradine's amendment, I believe in the approach that Senator Coulter has flagged-that is, perhaps it would be more appropriate to have attached to the Export Market Development Grants Amendment Bill a list of regulations containing the sorts of things which would not be appropriate to be eligible to receive an export marketing grant. I ask the Minister whether, in fact, any amendment passed now would also be of only six months duration.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

If nothing further was done in the Budget session, the Act and Senator Harradine's amendment, if adopted, would fall at the end of that six months period.

—I ask the Minister whether, if this amendment were passed now, it would also be possible for it to be superseded by further amendment as indicated by Senator Coulter-that is, having a list of the regulations attached to the Act instead of having one specific amendment which, I agree, stands out somewhat as perhaps giving the impression that honourable senators are opposed only to this sort of material not being eligible for export grants.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating today the Parliamentary Entitlements Bill 1990 which is a Bill for an Act relating to the provision of benefits to members of each House of the Parliament. The purpose of this Bill is generally to validate certain parliamentary entitlements which, as a result of a High Court decision, may be invalid, but specifically to validate retrospectively supplementary postal allowances to the members of the House of Representatives which the High Court found to be illegal. The reason for the Bill is that the Labor Government was caught in a shoddy, blatant attempt to use taxpayers' money to pay for an established Labor Party direct mail campaign at a coming election.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government, I believe quite untruthfully, publicly stated-in an attempt to justify its putting its hand in the till yet again-that the reason for the increase was to enable members to write to their constituents once a year. An example was given that in the United States members are able to write to their constituents at least once a year. What the Government did not mention was that in the United States members are prevented from using their postage entitlements for two months before an election. The Labor Government's purpose in granting this unlawful increase-which it now wished, as I repeat, to validate retrospectively-was to enable sitting members-particularly in marginal seats-to use the increase in the two months prior to the election. So here we have a dishonest statement. Why did the Government not come out in the first place and be honest with the Australian people and say that the reason it was increasing postal allowances quite arbitrarily from $9,000 a year for members of Parliament by an additional $20,000 was that it wanted to use the additional funds for a direct mail campaign in the election that was coming up?

Let me consider the background to this Bill. In November 1988, as one of its functions the Remuneration Tribunal determined, among other things, that postal allowances for members and senators would be $9,000 a year from 1 January 1989. Of course, the Tribunal considered other items in respect of senators' and members' entitlements such as salaries, electoral allowances, travel allowances, car transport, and so on. In July 1989, the then Minister for Administrative Services, Mr West, withdrew stamp allowances from the Tribunal's jurisdiction on the basis that they were an office facility and not an allowance. In August 1989, Cabinet-the Executive, not the Parliament-increased postal allowances for members of the House of Representatives from $9,000 to $30,525 a year.

Honourable senators will recall that the allowances for the Senate were not changed. The Government itself could have made a submission to the Tribunal for its own determination late in 1989. Why did it not do so? That is a good question. The reason would have to be-and there is none other-that it could not be certain as to what would be the determination of an independent tribunal. The election strategy of the Australian Labor Party was, to a large extent, based on direct mail of the umpteen letters that many people in marginal seats-and, I might say, not only Labor Party marginal seats-received during the election campaign. Direct mail is, of course, a costly exercise and what better place to get the money than from the long-suffering, unsuspecting taxpayer? If the Tribunal itself did not come up with an appropriate figure, the election strategy of the Labor Party was in total disarray.

On 8 September 1989 the honourable member for Menzies, the Hon. Neil Brown, mounted a High Court challenge on the basis that what the Executive did was illegal. At the same time, the then Leader of the Opposition specifically warned that, pending the High Court decision, members should not spend more than $9,000 as determined by the independent tribunal. As anticipated, on 1 March 1990, when the election campaign had started, the High Court found unanimously-five to nil-that the Government's action of supplementing postage by a whopping $20,000 was unlawful. In brief, the Court decided that the Executive could not substitute its own decisions for those of the Tribunal and that only legislation that deals explicitly with change or policy can bring about a change.

What was the response of the Government at the beginning of this election campaign? Notwithstanding the High Court decision, the then Minister for Administrative Services issued a press release. I might say that, under the decision made by the Cabinet and Government, the $30,500-odd was indexed. However, among other things the press release stated:

Members of Parliament can spend the full extent of their $30,982 postage entitlement confident in the knowledge that no reimbursement will be required in the absence of any further order from the court.
He went further and said:
Labor members, and those Coalition members which ignored Mr Andrew Peacock's instruction not to spend more than $9,000 will welcome the decision.

The then Minister claimed that he received, and perhaps even sought, friendly opinion which supported an election strategy already in place, including pooling of postage allowances for use in marginal coalition seats. After the election, and after the money had been spent, and apparently on quite different advice, we were all warned by the new Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus)-and he bears no responsibility for the past-that not only should we stop posting letters--

TALK.START.PARA: —He was a member of the Cabinet at the time.

—Senator Puplick is quite right; it was a Cabinet decision and he was a member of the Cabinet at the time. One can see the gang of four or five sitting there and saying, `We have this great election strategy-direct mail campaigns. We trialled it in the previous election in a few seats'. Curiously enough, I note that the person who discussed the Bill in the House of Representatives was the honourable member for Rankin (Mr Beddall), who was one of the people trialled during the previous election campaign on direct mail campaigns.

SPEECH.PARA: After the election and after the money had been spent, on different advice we were warned by the new Minister for Administrative Services that not only should we stop posting letters but that other entitlements that honourable members and honourable senators had received for many years may also be in doubt as a result of the High Court decision. It is not known whether or not they are, but most would agree that the Government was drawing a long bow and engaging in some scare tactics.

What we do know is that this legislation is before us because the Labor Government knew what it was doing when, to use one of Senator Walsh's favourite expressions, it put its snout in the public trough for electioneering purposes. It may be argued by some that the members, on a Minister's advice-incorrect advice-innocently spent the supplementary allowance. If the Labor Party has any principle at all it is its responsibility to reimburse those members, not the responsibility of the Australian taxpayers. This was an election strategy by a party in government, quite incorrectly, quite unlawfully, snatching taxpayers' money for its own purposes. It is worth changing the words of Scott to read: `O what a tangled web you weave when first you set out to deceive!'

I have heard it rumoured that the Government has been making noises that if this legislation is amended-I would like to foreshadow at this stage amendments to be put in the committee stage, which I think it is vital should be supported; there are some critical elements-the Government may consider withdrawing the legislation. That, if correct, is nothing more than blackmail and bluff, and my response to that is `so be it'. I do not know at this stage what the Democrats' position would be, but I ask them to consider their own slogans. We all remember the slogan used by a previous leader of the Democrats, Senator Don Chipp, as he then was. He came here, he said, to keep the bastards honest. In the last election campaign their slogan was `give a damn', or words to that effect.
We will support the validation of legitimate entitlements as outlined in the Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have not got your amendments. They have not been allowed to be circulated. We asked for them and were not allowed to have them.

—Senator Macklin interjects and says that he does not have our amendments. I just draw to his attention that I did provide him with those amendments. I outlined one additional amendment to Senator Macklin over the phone. I understand that the amendments which will be moved in the committee stage have now been circulated.
—No, they have not.

—They are being circulated. We will support the validation of legitimate entitlements as outlined in the Bill. What we will not support is the retrospective validation of the supplementary postal allowance which was found by the High Court to be illegal. As mentioned, we will be introducing amendments which are now being circulated and which reflect that principled stand, plus others which we believe will tidy up the legislation and ensure that the powers of the Remuneration Tribunal are not diminished in future by this Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Parliamentary Entitlements Bill 1990 covers a whole variety of matters essential in terms of benefits which are provided to members of both Houses of Parliament. This has been a relatively complex operation involving quite a number of difficult items. For example, I draw the Senate's attention to the schedules which are attached to this Act and which enunciate, amongst other things, a range of items such as papers which are provided in Parliament House and to electorate offices, Australian flags and printed material, postage-which Senator Parer has just addressed-personalised letterhead stationery, the acquisition of books from the Government Bookshop, photographic services which are provided, office accommodation and equipment, travel within Australia and travel overseas by parliamentary delegations.

SPEECH.PARA: Part II of schedule 1 refers to parliamentary officers and Ministers. The matters that interest most senators here are to do with staff and the entitlements of staff to travel. Caught up in this are a number of other entitlements which have been provided outside the Remuneration Tribunal party leaders, deputy leaders and shadow Ministers in terms of parliamentary duties.

So it is quite an extensive exercise that this Bill is now seeking to cover and to validate retrospectively. I do not intend going over the history of how this came about as I think most honourable senators are well aware of it. However, at the outset I repeat what I said on behalf of the party on 17 August last year. In a motion which was moved by Senator Lewis with regard to the postage element of this legislation I indicated on behalf of my party that we believed that the correct method by which all of these entitlements ought to have been provided was through the Remuneration Tribunal. We believe that the Tribunal was set up to deal with these matters and that it is the appropriate body to deal with them.

One of the reasons I put forward for that is that the entitlements of members of parliament are not only of interest to members of parliament but that, as members of parliament paid for by the taxpayers, members' entitlements are also of interest to taxpayers. The Remuneration Tribunal advertises at least once a year, as the words in the Act specify, and at least once a year there is a public inquiry. Anybody is entitled to make submissions with regard to any items that the Remuneration Tribunal is dealing with. So that opens up this exercise and, I think, in a very clear and direct way says to the people of Australia, `There are necessary resources for parliamentarians to be able to carry out their task. We will make a determination on the level of those resources and we seek your input'. As a matter of record, the amount of input has been minuscule but, nevertheless, the operation and the opportunity are necessary so that the system is open to scrutiny by the public.

As I said last year on 17 August with regard to that one matter, we felt that the correct method that the Government ought to have employed was to seek, as it is permitted to do under the Act, a determination from the Tribunal with regard to postage.

Considering the attitude that the Tribunal has normally taken, there is probably a reasonable assumption that the postage entitlement could have been significantly increased. The reason I say that is that the Tribunal has been of a mind that the entitlements that it wishes to see, and believes are arguable, for members of parliament have always been at a higher level than those which governments have wished to provide. The Government would not necessarily have had to take fright at going through what I believe was the correct course. It was open to the Remuneration Tribunal not to so determine, and that would have stayed.

I cannot quite share the Opposition's paranoia about the Government's exercise on this. During the election campaign my party suffered from the use of this exercise, but the Government sought to make those entitlements available only to members of the House of Representatives. Since Democrats are members of the Senate only it therefore follows that they were not involved in that entitlement of up to $30,000. Only members of my party were not involved in that particular item. Members of the Australian Labor Party, the Liberal Party and the National Party spent more than the entitlement that we are talking about.
No additional entitlement of $30,000 was provided to members of the Senate. However, from 1 July to 16 November, an additional amount of about $400 was provided to honourable senators.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was $462.

—Thank you, Senator Walters. It was in fact a supplementation with regard to indexation. The item that Senator Parer dwelt on-that is, the postage item-seems to have caught the attention of the media. I draw attention to some material which Stewart West, who was the Minister for Administrative Services at the time, tabled in the House of Representatives yesterday.

SPEECH.PARA: It makes interesting reading. It puts into perspective some of the items we are talking about. For example, until 1984 the provision of staff was a matter for the Remuneration Tribunal. Staffing was not referred to the Tribunal for its 1984 review. At that time two staff members were provided to each honourable senator. Of course, honourable senators know that the Executive has since increased this number to three. There was no High Court case with regard to that but certainly an analogy can be drawn to the postage issue that Senator Parer raised; that is, the matter was handled by the Tribunal, it was then removed from the Tribunal's control and the figure was then increased, but no item was provided.

In addition, the staff travel budget, which is now set at an annual pecuniary limit, is a definite amount of money. Until 1984, that amount was determined by the Tribunal. The matter has now been removed from the Tribunal's control. One can go on.

In taking over the duties of Leader of my party, I obviously had an interest in the entitlements provided to leaders of political parties. All entitlements are provided by government except the unlimited postage, which is an item mentioned in the Remuneration Tribunal as being provided to leaders and to some deputy leaders, although not ours, and to some Whips, although not ours.

A number of items are determined by the Remuneration Tribunal and a number are determined outside. Most honourable senators would agree that, having got to this point, it makes some sense to regularise the situation. Quite frankly, a very close look needs to be taken at this issue. It cannot be done in the heat of this debate. Obviously, political lines are drawn with regard to the postage items.

We believe that the Remuneration Tribunal ought to be able to look after that entire range and make determinations. The arguments then would have to be presented up-front and the matter would proceed in that way. There are other ramifications. For a long time my party has supported the idea that parliamentarians' salaries ought to be linked to Public Service salaries and ought to be determined by the industrial tribunals that are available to the rest of Australians rather than by a special tribunal. These matters need to be unravelled, disentangled and to be put on a firm and reasonable basis. I will discuss the issues raised by Senator Parer on behalf of the Opposition about the amendments which have been circulated in the chamber when we get to the committee stage.

I think it is important for people, when they want to try to get a correct understanding of this matter, to read all the documents which are available, including the High Court judgment. One thing about High Court judgments-I presume it is because the judges do not have anybody sitting in judgment on them by way of an appeals court-is that one can normally read those judgments; whereas judgments from lower courts are very difficult to follow. This application, which was brought by the Opposition and which was in part successful, sought initially a series of declarations. Amongst those declarations was the following:
. . . that the Minister had no power to alter the existing postage entitlement or to apply the public moneys of the Commonwealth in providing an increased postage allowance.
It was one of the declarations sought but not allowed by the High Court. The High Court allowed the demurrer in these terms:

. . . on the ground that the defendants have no power to apply public moneys of the Commonwealth by way of postage entitlement, additional to that prescribed by the existing determination of the Remuneration Tribunal.

That raises some significant problems. It is a highly specific exercise that is referred to, not a general one. If one reads the later opinions offered after this High Court judgment, one realises that the High Court, having confined itself to that item of something in addition to a determination, because of not granting the other determinations sought, was silent with regard to a vacated field.

The lawyers could make a great deal of money out of this exercise, undoubtedly already have and probably will go on doing so. It is important to draw the Senate's attention to that distinction. Most of the media reports have managed to get it totally wrong. Most people read the determinations and thought they had been granted. But had they ever bothered looking at the front page they would see that it shows that. Had they turned to the last page, page 20, they would have seen that the High Court judgment said:

There are difficulties, however, in the way of making the declarations which the plaintiff seeks. Although the plaintiff has an interest in knowing whether or not he is entitled to a supplementary allowance, there may be other persons who are not parties to these proceedings whose rights or liabilities would be affected by the making of the declarations sought by the plaintiff-
it refers to Australia Post, for example-
The desirable course to take in these circumstances is simply to allow the demurrer.

This is a much more limited exercise than the one that has been written about. It opens up the possibility for further challenges to get more specifications. One would hope that we may save both the time of the High Court and everybody else by avoiding that course. In terms of this piece of legislation, the Government has in fact recognised that the correct body to make these types of determinations at the end of the day is the Remuneration Tribunal. Hence, this will now be sent back to the Remuneration Tribunal for a determination.

There are, in fact, a number of concerns. I draw the attention of honourable senators to the fact that this piece of legislation seeks not only to make changes in respect of retrospectivity but also seeks to make amendments to the Remuneration Tribunals Act.

I have circulated in the chamber, on behalf of the Australian Democrats, an amendment to Schedule 2 which I think will make clear what I perceive to be the intent of subsection 3 (1) of the Remuneration Tribunal Act and which seeks to leave out subsection 7 (4) of that Act. As that amendment runs across part of one of the amendments that the Opposition intends to move, it may be better to leave debate on my amendment until we reach that point.

Yesterday Stewart West tabled in the House of Representatives a number of documents which have previously been sought by the Opposition parties under the Freedom of Information Act. It would seem to make a lot more sense, in terms of the way that the Government operates, if it provided these types of documents in an exercise such as this. The Government does not have the majority in this place. One cannot make a decision without these documents. When one reads them through, one wonders why somebody did not release them in the first place. It is far easier to operate if one has all the information which one needs in order to make a decision. I think it may have saved a lot of heartache if the documents had been provided when they were asked for.

There are some items in respect of which the Government might think there are some difficulties. For example, yesterday the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate) raised a particular problem with a document which everybody in the chamber accepted is something which ought not to be bandied around. In those cases I think there are other forms in which information could be provided-for example, in an edited form or in a confidential manner.

I hope that in the future in these debates the Government will be more open and up-front in providing this type of information to the Parliament and that it will not simply seek to adopt a secretive approach. If there are genuine reasons for not providing a document and making it public, those reasons and the edited versions ought to be provided to the relevant parties for their consideration. If that were done there would be fewer problems for the Government. Indeed, it would be a lot easier for senators to have all the information that they need in order to be able to make a judgment with regard to any legislation and, particularly, with regard to this piece of legislation that we have before us.

I reiterate the point that I made at the beginning of my speech. We believe, as will now happen, that these items ought to be a matter for determination by the Remuneration Tribunal. We said that in August and we reiterate it today. The parties and the Government will be able to go before the Tribunal and argue their case in open debate and the general community will be aware of the levels that are set.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. What has the Government done to carry forward its initiatives of last year in the field of chemical weapons and with regard in particular to its efforts to eliminate this particularly appalling form of weaponry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Since the Government-Industry Conference Against Chemical Weapons held in Canberra last year I have continued discussions and correspondence with United States Secretary of State Baker and other world leaders on chemical weapons issues. My officials have worked on an extensive program to bring to fruition the Government's objective of a comprehensive convention to ban chemical weapons and to provide for their destruction.

ANSWER.PARA: What we have been doing falls into a number of categories. Let me describe them each very briefly. In the first place, in promoting a broad based international dialogue between governments and the chemical industry on the forthcoming convention, we have worked for a representative meeting of international chemical industry figures to continue the momentum generated at the industry forum in Canberra last September. This meeting will take place in Geneva in late June.

Secondly, at that Government-industry conference I announced that a national chemical weapons secretariat would be established within my Department to prepare for the implementation in Australia of a convention. That secretariat has now been established, is functioning, and has commenced consultations with Federal and State Government departments and the chemical industry to determine how the convention will relate to existing legal framework and practices, and to ensure that the necessary steps are taken to facilitate our compliance with the convention. I may say that this initiative has, at the time it was announced and subsequently, prompted a great deal of interest from a number of other countries. We will be presenting a report to the conference on disarmament in Geneva which we hope will stimulate parallel approaches elsewhere.

In the third place, so far as the negotiations in Geneva for the convention themselves are concerned, I can report to the Senate that in recognition of our leading role in this area Australia was invited this year to be the coordinator for the Western group of negotiating countries in Geneva and the Australian delegation in Geneva has been increased in size to fulfil this task. The negotiations are proceeding well. Useful results have been obtained this year on the order of destruction of chemical weapons, on chemical weapons production facilities, on legal issues, on protective assistance, and on the clarification of that crucial verification and challenge inspections question. Challenge inspections have taken place in the course of developing that regime.

Fourthly, we are conducting bilateral talks on chemical weapons issues with a whole range of countries, most recently in India just last week during disarmament consultations. I may say that particularly satisfying in this respect have been the very frank and productive exchanges with the United States. I am pleased to note that we have had now United States acceptance of a full mandate for the Conference on Disarmament to commence final drafting of a convention, something that was long missing. We have had the United States willingness revealed this week to consider halting the production altogether of binary chemical weapons after the anticipated bilateral treaty with the Soviet Union due for signature at the summit at the end of this month.

Fifthly, we have the regional initiative on chemical weapons launched in 1988 to raise regional awareness. We now have a team of officials visiting regional countries exploring further steps, such as regional participation in a trial inspection of a chemical plant and training cooperation to facilitate implementation of the technical aspects of the chemical weapons convention in our region.

Finally, pending the entry into force of a verifiable chemical weapons convention, which we all want, not only are we cooperating closely with our own industry to ensure that it is not inadvertently linked with the supply of materials elsewhere for chemical weapons manufacture but also we are continuing to chair what is known as the Australia group of like-minded countries meeting in Paris which works informally to harmonise export controls to avoid assisting chemical weapons programs in order to preserve an environment conducive to total chemical disarmament.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. Is the Minister aware of recent reports in the media of the New South Wales State Government's refusal to cooperate in the process of creating a national salaries structure for teachers? What is the Government doing to increase the quality of teaching?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have in fact some information on this matter from the Minister for Employment, Education and Training who is of the view, and I think most people in this Parliament would agree, that most thinking Australians believe that there is a crisis of morale in the Australian teaching profession and that schools all over Australia are concerned about the quality of teaching suffering as a result of low teacher morale. The level of teachers' pay, the lack of opportunities for career advancement, inadequate and uncoordinated provision for upgrading teachers' skills have all, says the Minister, contributed to the declining status of teaching as a career.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister is concerned also that teaching no longer attracts the highest calibre of school leavers. For instance, in 1986 less than one per cent of entrants to teacher education courses in Queensland had tertiary education scores of less than 700. By 1988 this had increased to over 12 per cent. In its report on teacher quality, from which this data is obtained, the Schools Council said:

When it is realised that candidates with a TE score of 700 have some 60 per cent of year 12 students rated above them, there must be serious concern that many young people currently entering pre-service teacher education courses . . . do not rank highly on traditional measures of scholastic aptitude.

While the figures I mention relate only to Queensland, the Schools Council advises that the situation is likely to be no better in other States. The Government is concerned about this and the lack of enthusiasm amongst students to enter teacher courses. Mr Dawkins has therefore invited all parties, State and non-government employers, unions and the Federal Government, to participate in a national negotiation on the quality of teaching. The national negotiation aims to maximise the benefits of award restructuring and to implement lasting reforms in Australian schools which will improve the quality of teaching in our classrooms. He has also indicated that there has been enthusiastic participation from the teachers union in this national negotiation. Teachers unions from both public and private school sectors yesterday presented the Minister with an agreed union agenda. It is an agenda that goes far beyond traditional concerns of adversarial industrial relations. The unions themselves, acknowledging that education plays a central role in the reshaping of the economic future of Australia, have broadened their agenda.

It should also be noted that education is traditionally a State responsibility and the success of these negotiations will depend on the cooperation of State governments. At a preliminary meeting of Ministers last week the majority of States agreed to participate in assisting these particular negotiations. To assist in resolving the key issue of national rates for teachers Mr Dawkins will invite all his State colleagues, when he meets them on 1 June, to put a proposal to unions on the question of benchmark salaries for teachers.

In the current climate of uncertainty, particularly given the New South Wales State Government's refusal to cooperate in the process, the question of rates of pay for teachers is one that needs to be settled quite urgently and with a degree of cooperation. That lack of cooperation from New South Wales is obviously a major problem towards settlement of these negotiations. If agreement on salaries cannot be reached by the process Mr Dawkins has indicated that as Federal Minister he will set a benchmark for supplementing Commonwealth grants to schools. However, he also believes that it would be desirable to settle this issue as soon as possible without resorting to industrial action to enable the discussions on the more important issues of teacher quality to proceed.
