—The resident fascist.

—That is right. The 19 awards and dozens of job classifications that currently cover the waterfront will be reduced to one award and perhaps six to eight job classifications. Further, the unions, as a result of an initiative from Bill Kelty, fully supported by me-described by Mr Sharp in a press release as, I think, the `Collins-Kelty farce',-is rapidly progressing to a situation where an amalgamation of those 30 unions will occur. I must say it is interesting, in terms of the Opposition's position on these matters, to note that Mr Sharp, the shadow Minister for shipping and waterfront reform, has done nothing but attack that initiative. I was interested to see that the shadow Minister for industrial relations, Mr Howard, welcomed it. Clearly, the Opposition still does not have a fixed position on this very important issue. No doubt it will work it out over the next 12 months or so.

ANSWER.PARA: As a result of all of those negotiations between the parties, under the auspices of the Waterfront Industry Reform Authority, an in-principle agreement was arrived at late last year. I stress those words-`late last year'. That in-principle agreement contains the framework for real waterfront reform for the first time in 50-odd years. But it is important to understand, and I have said this publicly ever since taking the job on, that that in-principle agreement is simply a promise, albeit a substantive promise. The effectiveness of it is going to be determined only when that promise is implemented.

The two essential elements to that process are the completion of the award restructuring negotiations to reduce the 19 awards to one and the job classifications down to six or eight, and the negotiations of the enterprise agreements that are also an essential part of the reform process. There is an absolute nexus between these two things; they have to be negotiated together.

The timetable that has been established by WIRA has been, in many major aspects, adhered to. We currently have a situation where, as agreed, in terms of the reform that has already been accomplished, in excess of 250 gangway watchmen have already been retired from the industry. That involved the Government in an expenditure of something like $9m and will result, in that single job classification alone, in a saving to the industry of $30m a year recurrent, which indicates the extent of the reform process that can be made once these other job classifications are accomplished.

The program itself involves the retirement over the three-year period of the reform process of 3,000 older employees on the waterfront. These are older people with entrenched, fixed and myopic attitudes towards the way they carry out their jobs-something like Senator Walters.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Collins, this is a very long answer. It is becoming a statement, and I ask you to conclude your answer. You should also withdraw that remark.
—I am happy to conclude the answer.
—I am asking you to withdraw the remark.

—I withdraw unconditionally. The reason I am being a little lengthy in my answer-and I add that I have not repeated myself once in the answer; there is quite a lot to go yet in fact-is the emphasis that the Opposition had been placing on this issue as being so central to micro-economic reform; it is an important issue. But to conclude the answer, quite shortly, the facts are that there has in fact been considerable progress made, to answer Senator Walters's question, in waterfront reform.
—I raise a point of order, Mr President. The Minister is not only flagrantly breaching Standing Orders about not debating the reply, but he is also now flagrantly refusing to abide by your ruling.
—I have asked the Minister to conclude, and I am assuming he is doing that.

—The question was what progress has been made on waterfront reform, and I was in the process of saying, when the point of order was taken, that the progress has been considerable. There is a long way to go. I have made some public commitments that perhaps are a little unique about my involvement in that process, and I have no doubt that that reform process will be successfully accomplished.

—I have a supplementary question, Mr President. As the waterfront industry reform package was announced seven months ago, is the achievement that the Minister has told us about-that nothing actually has been done but that the parties are talking, which is an example of the speed of reform that Senator Collins calls significant-enough to save him carrying out his threat of resignation in 12 months time?
—The progress of waterfront reform currently is significant.

—Is the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade aware that refugee civilians from Myanmar have been returned to Myanmar against their will by the Thai authorities and have been subjected in Myanmar to gross human rights violations, including torture, imprisonment without trial, forced labour and, in some cases, execution? What action is the Minister taking to protest to the Thai authorities over their failure to honour widely accepted international obligations to these Myanmar refugees? Is the Minister also aware that the Congress of the United States, in order to protest against human rights violations by the Myanmar Government, is in the process of passing legislation banning imports from Myanmar? Will the Minister consider similar action to put pressure on the Government of Myanmar to cease violations of the rights of its citizens and to restore fundamental freedom?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the case that an intensified campaign by the Myanmar army has led to a substantial increase in the number of refugees from that country entering Thailand. There are now believed to be about 40,000 refugees in this category in Thailand, of whom about 28,000 are Karens. In addition, of an estimated 10,000 Myanmar students who took refuge in Thailand following suppression of the pro-democracy demonstrations in Yangon in September 1988, about 2,000 to 3,000 remain. Most of the returning students appear to have made their own way home. The Thai Government claims that a small number of refugees, mainly students, agreed to return to Myanmar voluntarily under arrangements made by the Myanmar and Thai authorities. The Myanmar Government denies that any of the students who returned under these arrangements have been mistreated.

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian Government is concerned over these reports, which are part of a wider picture of human rights abuses in Myanmar that include the arrest and detention of Opposition leaders, torture, and forced porterage to the army. The Australian Government has done all in its power to encourage an improvement in the human rights situation in Myanmar and has certainly urged the Myanmar Government to accede to the wishes of the population for democratic change.

Our embassies in Yangon and Bangkok have discussed with both government authorities the situation of the refugees on the Thai-Myanmar border, emphasising the high level of concern that exists in Australia, and I know particularly in this place, over the situation of the refugees, as well as talking about Australia's policy on refugees and human rights generally.

As to the latter part of the question, we are aware that the United States Senate has voted to ban imports of goods from Myanmar. However, until similar legislation is passed by the whole Congress, that will, of course, have no legislative effect. We do remain ready to consider any further action it might be appropriate to take to underline our human rights concerns. However, I should say that we have never previously suspended GSP preferences as a means of applying pressure to secure internal reform and I doubt that that would be an appropriate step in this instance. We have made it clear that we would give prompt and sympathetic consideration to any requests that might be made for humanitarian aid for the refugees on the border, and it is hoped that one such request that I am anticipating may soon be finalised in that respect.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. What is the Government's plan for the Chinese students who have remained in Australia since the massacre in Tiananmen Square? Does the Minister acknowledge the difficult situation these students face if they return to China? Further, is there a plan to reunite them with their families by allowing these families to migrate to this country?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —It should be noted that at the end of January this year there were some 19,400 People's Republic of China (PRC) nationals temporarily in Australia who were here either on 4 June last year or at the time of the suppression of the pro-democracy movement or who had arrived by 20 June 1989, when the PRC Government introduced systematic checks on departing citizens. It should also be noted that, in addition, some 1,100 of those in Australia in June have since departed. The Majority of the PRC nationals temporarily in Australia in June were short-course trainees, mainly here to undertake English language courses. Tertiary students also formed a much smaller group. It should be noted that many of them had already overstayed their entry permits.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government's response is in fact based on the premise of Senator Jones's question-that of recognition of the problem of the students. The response so far has been fourfold. Firstly, we have made provision for those reluctant to return to China at this stage to remain in Australia until 31 January 1991. Secondly, if they do have long term concerns about returning, they may apply for refugee status. Thirdly, in respect of those who were legally here on 20 June, they may also apply for resident status on humanitarian grounds, provided that they hold an enabling entry permit. Fourthly, it should also be noted that no special provisions have been made for PRC nationals who arrived after 20 June last year. However, some have already applied for refugee status.

The Government also notes that several thousand applications have already been received for refugee status and humanitarian resident status from PRC nationals. The further response from the Government will be based on the question of the need to process the applications, which at this stage far exceed normal numbers. We will soon be looking at this issue to see how we can better handle the massive number of applications that have come from this part of the community.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications. Is the Minister aware that the proposed new Broome airport in Western Australia, as a joint venture between Ansett Airlines of Australia and McAlpine's Australian City Properties Ltd, has been shelved? Can the Minister explain why, considering the Federal Government had agreed to sell the old airport to the Broome Shire Council in return for the development of the new one?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The short answer to Senator Panizza's question is, quite simply, because the consortium withdrew. That is a matter of regret to the Government. Of course, the Government is pursuing with some vigour the matter of handing over airports for local ownership, which is something I support very strongly as a principle. We were very keen to pursue the proposal that was put up for the Broome airport by Lord McAlpine and Ansett working together to commercially develop the airport. Not surprisingly, apart from anything else, there was a distinct financial advantage for the Commonwealth Government in pursuing that option, as well as for the Broome community.

ANSWER.PARA: The situation is that as a result, presumably, of the commercial judgment of the people involved-and it was simply expressed as an interest that we were pursuing originally-they have now indicated they are not interested in pursuing it. A decision will be taken by me this week to pursue other avenues of continuing the negotiations, as we intend to do, with the local community in Broome for local ownership of the airport.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a supplementary question, Mr President. I thank the Minister for some of his answer. Can he tell me whether one of the reasons for shelving the project was a hold-up in transferring the airport from the Federal Government to the Broome Shire Council via the Western Australian State Government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the reasons for the delay, and it was an important matter, was obtaining a proper valuation of the property. That is crucial to a proper outcome for any government, in order to get the best value for money for its property. If we had not done that we would have been held properly to account in this Parliament and, no doubt, have got a severe hiding in Estimates committees. As a result, a number of valuations were obtained, but people had real concern about the valuation of the property.

ANSWER.PARA: It is also fair to say-because it became a matter of some public controversy, as I am sure Senator Panizza is aware-that concerns were also expressed about possible conflicts of interest in respect of the Broome Shire Council, involving particular individuals in the consortium as well. Really, that was the major reason for any delay-not that I think any real delay did occur-in transferring the airport.

It is likely that the proper course of action that may now be available to the Government is simply to call for expressions of public interest in pursuing private ownership of the airport in conjunction with the Broome Shire Council. Certainly that is one of the options I am currently considering.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Has the Minister seen reports alleging that a clothing company operating in the trade development zone (TDZ) in Darwin has withheld from its employees wages and other entitlements provided for in the Federal clothing trades award? Do these reports suggest that these employees are overseas guest workers, many of them women? Are the reports correct? If so, can he advise the Senate what action has been taken to recover from the company the wages and entitlements to which its employees are entitled?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I have seen a report. Indeed, there is a long article in today's Business Review Weekly concerning the Darwin trade development zone. The article is headed `Darwin's disaster zone' and reports a series of quite horrendous human rights infringements. If those allegations are true, they would be quite alien to the Australian way of life and attitudes. The article reports as well allegations concerning underpayment of wages. I am concerned that those allegations have been made in terms of industrial relations responsibilities in that workers have been underpaid.

ANSWER.PARA: The Department of Industrial Relations has conducted a thorough investigation into the claims of breaches of the clothing trades award at Hengyang Darwin Pty Ltd and is currently conducting further investigations into Hengyang Holdings Pty Ltd and Darwin International Textiles Pty Ltd. I should say that Hengyang Darwin and Hengyang Holdings are Hong Kong-based clothing and textile companies. The claims involve underpayments and employment conditions breaches of guest workers who went to work in the trade development zone from Guangdong province in the People's Republic of China.

I should report that the investigations into Hengyang Darwin and Hengyang Holdings have been significantly hampered by a complete absence of the normal time and wages records. Amounts owing have had to be deduced by production figures and export figures, making investigations more difficult. My Department sent a letter, I think yesterday, to the solicitors acting for the two companies acknowledging the companies' admission of award breaches and providing an analysis of the extent of the underpayment of the guest workers. Our analysis suggests that the underpayments are in the order of half a million dollars or more. The officers of my Department will be meeting with representatives of the company in Darwin early next week in an attempt to settle this matter.

The Federal Government remains committed to the effective development of the industrial base of the Northern Territory and the concept of a trade development zone as such. However, that commitment is not a commitment to support the concept at any cost in terms of industrial relations or human rights. The Federal Government will consider the renegotiation of the suspended tripartite negotiated agreement between us, the unions and the TDZ authority only if the current situation is resolved in line with normal Australian standards. We will continue to monitor the situation in the Darwin TDZ, especially the maintenance of effective industrial relations agreements and arrangements which may allow guest workers into the zone. I should record in the Senate that, along with my colleagues the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Northern Australia, Senator Collins, the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, Mr Hand and the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, Mr Dawkins, I am appalled at the breaches of human rights that I have referred to.

The major reason for the breaches of award conditions in the zone has been, undoubtedly, the very lax attitude of the Northern Territory Government in its administration of the TDZ's affairs. This is something that the article in the Business Review Weekly is unrestrained in saying. The Northern Territory Government is responsible, in the legal sense, for issuing licences for foreign companies operating in the TDZ and must accept the responsibility for the situation that has developed. The buck does stop on Marshall Perron's desk. It is not something that the Northern Territory Government can shirk the responsibility for; it must face up to it publicly. We, as a department, will continue to try to retrieve the money owed to those workers and settle at least that part of the matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce to the serious damage being caused to Australian horticultural industries, such as peanuts, citrus, dried fruit, apple juice and canned vegetables, by cheap, inferior quality products exported from countries classified by the Australian Customs Service as developing.
—Peanuts, boy!

—If the honourable senator listens to this, he will learn something. In view of the fact that these imported products receive a 5 per cent tariff preference even though, in many cases, other Western countries, including the United States and New Zealand, no longer give these now wealthy countries developing country preferences, will the Minister consider a complete review of the developing country tariff preference with a view to either abandoning it or restricting it to genuine developing countries or industries rather than the current system of broad tariff preference?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure that I heard all of the question because Senator Boswell's distant colleague Senator Puplick was attempting to interject at the time Senator Boswell asked the question, but I think I understand the burden of it. It is true that under successive Australian governments various countries which are described as developing countries have been given preference under the tariff system which operates in Australia. That preference used to extend sometimes to 15 or 10 per cent until the Government reviewed the matter about four years ago through a committee under the chairmanship of Professor Helen Hughes, the Committee for Review of Export Market Development Assistance. It was subsequently recommended that the level of that tariff preference given to developing countries should be 5 per cent and not the various levels it had been in the past.

ANSWER.PARA: I regard it as very important that Australia give tariff preferences to countries such as the Philippines, India and perhaps Vietnam, where there is very genuine poverty and low per capita incomes. I think one of the best things Australia can do is try to assist the raising of per capita incomes in those countries by facilitating their exports. That has been a policy of successive governments.

TALK.START.PARA: —Regardless of what they spend on armaments.

—In spite of Senator Puplick's noisiness it has been a policy espoused and supported by the Opposition throughout its history. It is a bipartisan policy, and it was this Government, as I pointed out earlier, which reviewed the level of the tariff preference and had it reduced.

ANSWER.PARA: Australia is a member of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT). For five or six years GATT has been reviewing the system of tariff preferences which are operated around the world, and some countries have argued for what is called the graduation of preferences, that is to say, they would like to take Korea and Singapore out of the preference system. Last year, I think, the United States unilaterally took its preference system away from the four `tigers', that is, Korea, Taiwan, Hong Kong and Singapore. But that was not done as a matter of tariff policy. That was done to punish those countries for refusing to devalue their currencies. That is what that was about. The United States of America can do that sort of thing; I am not sure that Australia is in a position to do it.

We certainly have been supporting the GATT review. The last figures I saw-1988-show that per capita incomes in Singapore reached $US10,800 year in 1988. Average per capita incomes in Australia are something of the order of $US12,500. So the gap between Singapore and Australia has closed. The gap between Australia and other countries which I have mentioned, such as Vietnam and India, is enormous, and we will certainly continue that policy for the time being until GATT finally reviews the matter and announces its decision.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy explain whether the Government guarantees to the Australian Wool Corporation (AWC) to borrow up to $2.5 billion to help fund the wool stockpile enables the Wool Corporation to receive a concessional interest rate? How much has the Wool Corporation borrowed to date and have those borrowings added to Australia's foreign debt?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —In answer to the first question, the borrowings by the Wool Corporation do not attract any concession. They are a commercial transaction, as I am advised. The Wool Corporation can presently borrow up to half of its net assets, which is about $1.025 billion. Any additional borrowing beyond that limit will have to be agreed between the Corporation and the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Kerin. Senator Schacht asked how much has been borrowed. I am advised that the AWC has borrowed about $800m at the present time, but with an estimated borrowing of $1.1 billion at this rate by 30 June this year.

ANSWER.PARA: In terms of the element of the question dealing with foreign debt, the borrowings by the Australian Wool Corporation have been mainly, up to this point, local. However, any further borrowings would be expected to come from overseas sources and thus have an impact on foreign debt. As I think honourable senators will know, naturally the Government has already introduced into the House legislation to rectify the problem. Shortly it will be coming to the Senate and no doubt we will have a lively debate about it when it gets here.

Currently there are 2.4 million bales of wool in stockpile in Australia and if they were sold they would earn-in terms of the export side of our current account-between about $2 3/4 billion and $3 billion and that would be a very useful transaction. But if they continue to stockpile because the floor price is too high to reflect the needs of the market at the present time we could look forward to our stockpile growing to about six million bales and the Australian Wool Corporation's peak borrowing requirement blowing out to $3.5 billion, which would then be $2.4 billion net addition to the total foreign debt. That is on the figures that the AWC itself put out-they are not Government figures. The situation does need to be rectified and we will do that as soon as the legislation passes this chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs whether he supports recent calls by the Australian Council of Trade Unions for the amalgamation of some of Australia's 835 municipal councils? If so, can the Minister indicate what procedures the Government will be implementing as part of the amalgamation process? Can the Minister given an indication of the number of councils which will be scrapped if the amalgamation process proceeds?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the report that Senator Calvert refers to is the one that was launched by Mr Martin Ferguson, the President of the ACTU. It was in fact a report from the Evatt Foundation the name of which, I believe, was Breach of Contract. It should be noted that local government throughout Australia has for some time been grappling with the question of amalgamation, but essentially it should also be noted that the question is one which is very much at the heart of efficiency of local government, the structure of local government, being one basically of State responsibility.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Calvert, with his interest in the area, would know that originally there were about 1,000 councils in Australia, but over time this has declined, although the reduction in the numbers has slowed over the last 15 or so years. Currently we have 836 councils. It should also be noted-as I say in the framework of the fact that we are talking about State responsibility-that from time to time States do examine the question of amalgamation. There was a round of amalgamations in New South Wales in the early 1980s and Victoria also opened up the question of amalgamation when the Cain Government came to power, but the issue was rejected at local level. At an even more local level in my own suburb in Adelaide, a council that could and should have been amalgamated quite recently resisted that amalgamation. As I said, it is fair to say that the issue goes to structural efficiency in local government, but other than to say that we see it as primarily a State responsibility, there is nothing more constructive I can add.

I ask Senator Calvert and the Senate to note that the Federal Government has been involved in a range of issues and provision of services and facilities to enhance the efficiency of local government organisations and also, of course, to enhance the level of management skills in those organisations through different programs that were initiated under Senator Margaret Reynolds and Ministers before her.

I cannot provide precise figures as to the number of councils that would be eradicated. Suffice it to say, the report Breach of Contract, being an Evatt Foundation report, is important for government and councils to consider in the whole framework of obtaining better efficiency in government in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for the history lesson on local government, but I repeat: Does the Minister support Martin Ferguson and the Australian Council of Trade Unions calling for the amalgamation of councils. Is that or is that not the Government's position?
—I have answered the question, and the point I made in response to that part of it was that we see the Evatt Foundation report as a useful document as part of the overall debate.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. Is it a fact that the Minister presented a cheque for $1 3/4m to the Tasmanian shipbuilding firm International Catamarans (Tasmania) in July 1989 as a progress payment under what were described as the new shipbuilding bounty arrangements? What further payments have been made to International Catamarans? What payments will be made in the future? What plans have the Minister or other Ministers of the historic fourth Hawke Administration for making use of Tasmanian built catamarans? Will Tasmanian catamarans be employed in future for Australian military use, Australian coastal surveillance, Australian fisheries patrols, or perhaps Australian search and rescue operations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —International Catamarans is an excellent example-sadly, we do not have too many-of an innovative Australian manufacturer that has become very successful in the international shipbuilding industry.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator MacGibbon interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to Senator MacGibbon's interjection-we had no international shipbuilding industry when this Government came to power; in fact, we had no shipbuilding industry at all, because it had been destroyed during the period of the Fraser Government. If Senator MacGibbon wants to interject and if wants to walk into the kitchen, he will get a bit of heat. The fact is that Australia now has an export industry in shipbuilding, of which about $500m per year is earned in export earnings, and that is growing. International Catamarans is one of the most successful of those export companies, and it is true that it is eligible for the shipbuilding bounty.
—It holds the record for crossing the Tasman.

—Senator Watson is on the ball; he is better than Senator MacGibbon; he knows what is happening down there in Tasmania. But the payment to which the honourable senator refers was made in respect of a catamaran called Hoverspeed Great Britain. That ship is now complete. It will go to Britain via New Zealand and it will be used on the English Channel run by a major British ferry operator. The honourable senator asked about payments to the company under the bounty scheme. They were about $2 5/8m for the first vessel, $1 2/3m for the second, and so on. Future payments will be made in accordance with the rates of bounty specified in the Act, which terminates on 30 June 1995. The exact amount is dependent on the value of production and the date on which the production takes place.

ANSWER.PARA: The honourable senator asked whether the Australian Government and its agencies were aware of the quality and performance of International Catamarans' product, and the answer to that question is yes. Currently, International Catamarans has five vessels under order for Sea Containers Limited of London, most of which will be used on the cross-Channel run. Five more possible orders are in the pipeline. The total value of those 10 vessels will be in excess of $250m. The vessels currently being built in Hobart are up to 74 metres in length. They can accommodate 450 passengers and 85 motor vehicles. They are already used extensively on the Great Barrier Reef, in China, Thailand, the United Arab Emirates, England, the United States of America, and Indonesia.

With reference to the question of Commonwealth Government agencies, I am sure those agencies are aware of the quality and performance of the product of International Catamarans. But, of course, the ones currently being produced are considerably larger than any requirement that would exist for a Commonwealth agency. In conclusion, the catamaran Hoverspeed Great Britain, which is now on its way to the United Kingdom, has made a formal challenge for the fastest passenger vessel crossing the Atlantic, for which there is a trophy. That Atlantic crossing will be made in June and I am sure that honourable senators, even Senator MacGibbon, will join me in wishing the company and the crew of that catamaran every success in their attempt to break the Atlantic record.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, before the next question is asked, since that last question was clearly a question of which notice had been given, I ask that Senator Button table the written answer from which he was reading.
—It is a decision for the Minister as to whether he will table it or not.
—I am not obliged to table anything, but I will; I have no problem with it.

—My question is to you, Mr President. Are you aware that the average number of questions a day in the Senate has fallen from 33.4 in 1971 to 16.4 last year? Do you believe that the parliamentary process of scrutinising the Executive is well served by both the existing Question Time procedures and the manner in which Ministers have been responding to questions? Will you consider allowing supplementaries from around the chamber as happens in some other parliaments, until, in your view, the issue has been resolved, to ensure that Ministers cannot continue to filibuster through one question with one supplementary but nonetheless not give an answer. Finally, will you support a review of Question Time procedures with a view to ascertaining the merits or otherwise of systems such a those used in the United Kingdom or Canada?

—In reply to Senator Vanstone, I am aware that a number of figures have been taken out as to the number of questions asked during Question Time. There has been some dispute in the past as to how supplementaries have been counted. I will take the rest of the question on notice. I point out to the Senate that yesterday I think we had the most questions answered of any day that I can remember since I have been in the chamber; I think it was 28. Unfortunately, today has not been as good, but I will look at the issues raised by Senator Vanstone and present a report to the Senate.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Can the Minister tell the Senate how many companies had reported on affirmative action programs by 30 April this year? What are the results? Can the Minister advise the Senate on the performance of the Affirmative Action Agency?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Affirmative Action (Equal Employment Opportunity for Women) Act, one of this Government's strategies to ensure that women have equal opportunities in status and employment, requires employers to report on the progress of their workplace programs for women. Progress reports from the private sector are due to be lodged with the Affirmative Action Agency by 30 April each year. To date the response to the Act from both the private sector and higher education institutions has been commendable. Last year 97 per cent of companies and 100 per cent of higher education institutions lodged reports with the Agency. The eight private sector companies that failed to do so were named in Parliament by my predecessor in November.

ANSWER.PARA: This year, 1990, is an historic year for the Act, with approximately 2,800 progress reports expected from the private sector. This is the first year in which those companies employing between 100 and 500 employees will be reporting to the Agency on their plans for ensuring that women have equal opportunities at work. As the honourable senator will know, these smaller companies became subject to the Act in early 1989.

As to 10 May, the Agency had received 1,548 reports from the private sector and 64 reports from higher education authorities. This represents a reporting rate of 55.3 per cent in the private sector and 94 per cent in the higher education sector. Whilst it is concerning that so many reports are still outstanding, the reporting pattern this year is similar to that of previous years. For example, in 1989 fewer than half the reports from the private sector, 46 per cent, were lodged within the statutory reporting period.

On 7 May the Affirmative Action Agency sent notices to all companies which had not yet reported, reminding them of the Act's sanction. The Agency is currently analysing those results and expects that it will deal with the matter fully in its annual report.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In the light of those figures, with only about 55 per cent of companies reporting on time, will the Minister consider amending the legislation to incorporate stricter reporting provisions?
—Naturally I am concerned about tardy reportees. However, the Affirmative Action Agency is reviewing its own legislation in full. It is a matter I would like to take on during that review.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —During Question Time on 9 May Senator Reid directed a question to Senator Richardson concerning the presence of asbestos in the Gowrie Hostel. Senator Richardson advised that he could answer Senator Reid's question yesterday but we were not able to. The Department of Administrative Services, which has responsibility for Gowrie Hostel, became aware of the presence of some asbestos in the building following a preliminary survey on 1 February 1990. The Government decided to sell the lease over Gowrie Hostel on 20 July 1989. The Department and the Government were un- aware of the presence of some asbestos at the time the decision was taken to dispose of Gowrie. Therefore, it was not, I am informed, a factor in the decision.

TALK.START.PARA: —Once again we have caught the Government with its hand in the till of taxpayers' money. There is no doubt at all that this Government knew full well when it decided to take the stamp allowance out of the hands of the Remuneration Tribunal that it had no right to do so. Because an election was so close it chose, above all else, to try to win the election by fair means or foul. Then the Government chose to give to each Labor member of the House of Representatives $30,500 of taxpayers' money, as a postal allowance.

SPEECH.PARA: People do not earn that sort of money. The average wage is well below that. Those who are presently getting the average wage are being taxed to give members of the Labor Government enough money-$30,500 each-to write letters to every person in his or her electorate. It was a disgraceful act and adds to the numerous times that this Government has been called before the High Court by members of the Opposition.

We all remember very well the situation during one of the referendum debates early in the life of this Government when Senator Gareth Evans attempted to appropriate special money for the Government's case, the Yes case. He hid that appropriation in the ministerial slush fund. We all remember that well. He thought that he could diddle the Senate, not let it know that special money had been appropriated for his campaign, and attempted, quite illegally, to use taxpayers' money, apart from that allowed by law.

When we asked why he had not told us where that extra money was stashed, he said, `You didn't ask'. Again, the Government has been caught doing exactly the same thing. When the initial letter was received by all of us, Mr Peacock, as our Leader, knowing that it was wrong, immediately issued a statement saying that we should not use that allowance. He wrote to each member of the House of Representatives saying, `Do not use it'.

Even when we threatened High Court action, the Government was too clever by half. It decided that the election was on the way and that it must give its members an appropriation over and above that of any other candidate running against it in that campaign. The Government had a majority in the House of Representatives of about 20 members and it knew that it would be a great asset to have an additional $30,000 to spend in respect of 20 dicey seats. The other candidates, of course, were denied any money at all.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thirty thousand dollars of taxpayers' money.
—Yes, $30,500 of taxpayers' money. Indeed, when postal rates went up the Government decreed that the amount would also rise. So it ended up with $30,982-nearly $31,000.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government had made the decision. We decided, once again, to take it to the High Court and we won. The High Court decided that it was illegal, that the Remuneration Tribunal should make those judgments and that the Government had no right to take the matter out of the hands of the Remuneration Tribunal.

The High Court ruled a third time against this Government in respect of the Government's over-zealous advertising during the last referendum. The Government used blatant advertising in a, so-called, non-party political way. We took the Government to the High Court and, once again, we won. The Government had to withdraw that advertising.

The matter before us today is nothing short of theft of taxpayers' money. The decision to bring retrospective legislation before this Chamber in order to overturn the High Court's decision cannot be accepted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister is not even listening to you.

—I wish that the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) would sit down and listen to the debate. I believe that he should conduct his portfolio in a polite way. I will not speak for any longer. I believe that this debate should be wound up so that, as of today, the ruling can be made and those moneys that have been used illegally can be returned to the coffers of the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: (Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak to the Parliamentary Entitlements Bill 1990, and want to go to the question of the Remuneration Tribunal. The Tribunal has been set up by the Parliament to look after many functions involving parliamentarians and other officers. That is what it is for, and that is what it does. It has been a very responsible body. I believe that if any body has been irresponsible it has been governments past and present; the Tribunal has not been irresponsible towards government.

SPEECH.PARA: The main issue under debate at the moment is the postage stamps allowance for members of the House of Representatives. Certainly I would agree that a case put properly to the Tribunal would succeed in getting an increase in the allowance, particularly for some of those electorates where there is a large changeover of registrants. I heard one member of the House of Representatives saying that in a particular electorate there was a changeover in the order of 1,200 a month. The stamps used to contact those people just once would be fairly expensive.

I object to the way that members of the House of Representatives got the increase in their stamp allowance. It is an insult to the integrity of the Parliament for a proposition like this to be put forward and so massively misrepresented. I know, and I think every parliamentarian knows, that over the last few years the Government has been carrying out a considerable amount of research into the question of direct mail as a matter of electioneering. Having moved to get public funding of elections and having decided that that was insufficient to perform the duties that the Government would like it to do, it was then a matter of how we would get around the legislation, of whether there was a possibility of getting an extension of public funding one way or the other. We know what the right way is. The right way starts with coming clean. If that is what the Government wants that is what it should try to do. To achieve this by deception and misrepresentation, as was done, is not good enough.

The direct mail operation was considered. It was tested and trialled. It was regarded as being satisfactory so it had to be introduced. It could not be done too openly or too early in the peace. It was just not possible for the Government to come out and say, `We have got this brand new system of electioneering and we would like to use it and we need you to know all about it so that you can use it too'. Nothing was further from its mind. The system enabled the Government to see how late it could leave it, how it could get it through and how it could make sure it got an advantage from it that the others would not get.

The misrepresentation was built around quoting what happens in the United States. Deliberate untruths were told on this question. The matter was raised and the Government said that all it was doing was what had been found necessary in the United States. It had been found necessary that members should have the opportunity of making regular contact once a year with their constituents. If this were to be achieved in Australia it would require a magical figure of $30,000. The difference is that in America it may not and must not be used during the election campaign. There is a strict rule preventing any of that money being used within two months of the election. In this case I venture to suggest that probably 90 per cent of the money that was spent was certainly spent within two months of the election. We are talking about the fact that it was purely and simply an extension of public funding for sitting members. Having a substantial majority of members, say it was 20, at $30,000 each that is an extra $600,000 for the coffers of the Government to fight the next election. That is a fairly good start in times of difficult financial constraints.

The Government found out that the operation was at risk. We notified the Government from the first day that we thought its actions were illegal and contrary to the law as we saw it. It just became another grubby little exercise. It falls back on the general philosophy that one tries it if one can. If one gets away with it all well and good. If one cannot get away with it one fixes it. Who is responsible? Do we or do we not still have a thing called ministerial responsibility or is ministerial responsibility, as we saw yesterday, one of the things that is unimportant if it means the alternative of covering for ones mates. We have seen this with the Paddington bear issue and things like that.

Are we in Australia or is this Colombia, Cambodia, Venezuela or somewhere like that? We need to consider what this Government has done and the basis for it. Is it getting to the stage where the Government says, `We will do anything that is necessary as a means of winning an election'? If the Government passes laws that are invalid, makes decisions that are wrong, and the courts throw them out, the Government says, `We will change the law and make it retrospective'. The next move is to say `Let's abolish the Tribunal as well because it did not give us what we asked for'. That is not the way in which this country should be run; I hope it never has been and I hope it never will be. Frankly, I do not trust the Government. If the case had ever been truthfully stated, if there had been an expose at the time as to what was going on, I think more people would have understood. But the situation was willfully, wantonly and knowingly misrepresented. I am sure that the Australian Democrats understand this. I believe that they, too, would fully appreciate the misrepresentation and the effect that it had on the electorate.

There is no way that I can support, or that the Opposition can support, this particular item. I will deal only with this item. The fact is that it was taken out of the hands of the Tribunal when there was never any justification for that happening. It was done under a cloak of misrepresentation and the figure was grossly excessive, anyway. I will not support the Bill, nor will anybody, I believe, who is concerned in any way about parliamentary propriety.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Parliamentary Entitlements Bill 1990-a Bill for an Act relating to the provision of benefits to members of each House of Parliament. The truth of the matter is that we are debating legislation which retrospectively visits upon members of the House of Representatives an entitlement to expend $30,000 on stamps, an increase of approximately $20,000. If it had not been for the naked grab for power by this Government, this legislation would not be before us now. It is before us now because this delinquent, promiscuous Government was prepared to plunder the public purse to help itself get re-elected and, in the process, suspend all the traditional provisions which accommodate members' and senators' entitlements.

SPEECH.PARA: It is not without significance to note that the benefit was not accruing to senators-only to members of the House of Representatives. The Bill before us now does not seek to provide any additional benefit in respect of the stamp allowance for senators, but simply to legislate, as I say, retrospectively, for a benefit granted by the Government illegally to members of the House of Representatives.

Where is the logic in increasing the benefit, in the face of disapproval by the Remuneration Tribunal, to members of the House of Representatives and not to senators? Did the Government consider making some additional provision for senators or did it simply wish to give this bag of stamps to members of the House of Representatives? The answer rests in the latter comment: it is simply an increase for members of the House of Representatives. The reason is quite simple. If a party has a majority in either House and imposes a benefit, the majority of the benefit flows to that political party. Because the Government has a majority in the House of Representatives, the Government, on balance, receives the greater benefit.

The reason that the Senate was excluded from this appropriation was that the Government has a minority of numbers in the Senate, and if equal funding had been provided to the Senate the Government would not have been so benefited in the granting of the stamps. That is why the Senate was excluded. The reason that it was given to the House of Representatives was to assist in the re-election of members of the House of Representatives. If one happens to be in government, if one happens to have the majority of the numbers and if one is successful in the execution of that pursuit, it means that one will get re-elected-and that is what this was all about.

The Government was advised of the strong disapproval of the Opposition. It was subsequently advised of the Opposition's intention to prosecute its views through the High Court. But rather than set aside for the moment the Government's capricious determination, waiting to see the outcome of the resolution of the High Court action, the Government pursued its endeavour for the purpose of ensuring the re-election of the majority of members of the House of Representatives.

Why is it that the granting of these additional funds coincided with the timing of the election? It demonstrates that the funding was not an endeavour to ensure that over a 12-month period or the life of the Parliament members of the House of Representatives had a greater capacity to communicate with their constituents; otherwise, knowing the High Court action was afoot, the Government could have set aside its determination until after the election and allowed that extra communication to proceed. But the Government was determined to jam this money into the offices of members of the House of Representatives to make sure it was expanded prior to the election. I would be very interested to find out what portion of that $31,000 was not expended by Government members in the House of Representatives. Almost without exception, the full amount of money has been spent; it was spent for the purpose of ensuring that members of the House of Representatives were re-elected.

Turning for a moment to the equivalent entitlements to senators, what is the logical, rational argument that might be presented to us against an equal entitlement being given to a senator? Presumably, Senator Bolkus will address himself to that issue when he rises to conclude the debate. But there seems to be some cute and peculiar view in the mind of the Government that senators do not have constituents, they do not have a relationship with their community, they do not have responsibilities in terms of constituents, and they do not have responsibilities towards the wider community-as if they are some discrete group, divorced and isolated from the electorate. That argument seeks to say that there is no political or public accountability by the members of the Senate, elected by the same people who elect members of the House of Representatives, as if, once a senator is endorsed by his political party, the umbilical cord is cut, that he has no intrinsic relationship with his electorate, but a member of the House of Representatives has that. Those of us who discharge our responsibilities properly know that to be quite untrue.

I am not here to argue the merit of any increase in the stamp allowance. I am arguing that there was no integrity in the Government's endeavours and no balance in the resolution of the determination. The Government simply set aside these funds for the purpose of using public moneys to assist in guaranteeing the re-election of the Hawke Government for a dubious fourth term. It is not without significance to note that the legislation is by its very nature retrospective in its application. A compelling argument can be put that, in respect of the stamps, this legislation should apply from the date of proclamation. Presumably the Government will argue that there are other benefit entitlements that can be included, but they are in a separate and distinct category and in no way impinge upon the determination to provide additional stamps.

This leads me to ask the question: why is it that the Government had unilaterally to take from the Tribunal the responsibility in respect of the stamp allowance determination? It was because the Government knew that if it had referred the term of reference to the Tribunal, the Tribunal would not have found in favour of an additional $21,000 for members of the House of Representatives. That is why the Government sat around and had this grubby little debate on how it could guarantee that it could rip off the taxpayers and be immune from any scrutiny. The Government was not prepared to refer this matter to the Tribunal because it knew the Tribunal would not agree to this grab for taxpayers' funds.

The Tribunal has previously found, rightly or wrongly, for better or for worse, that members of the House of Representatives are required to have an expenditure of only slightly in excess of $9,000 for the purpose of communicating by post with their constituents. This Government, believing that it has some pristine, unique wisdom, determined that they need three times that. The amount of money required for the members of the House of Representatives to communicate with their constituents is about the same amount as average weekly earnings. I do not have the figures before me, but $30,000 represents a lot of letters. One can be certain no member of the House of Representatives would be signing letters to the equivalent of $30,000 postage. What they will be doing is sending out junk mail to their constituents, seeking to persuade them that this is a government that is deserving of being re-elected.

If this Government had been honest, it would have increased public funding to accommodate the additional money. But it could not do that because that would not have benefited the Government. For instance, in Western Australia the Labor Party got 35 per cent of the primary vote. Australia wide it got 39 per cent of the primary vote. If it were relying on public funding, it would be disadvantaged. The big advantage the Labor Party has, as I said earlier, in granting to members of the House of Representatives an increase in the allowance is that it is of benefit to the majority of that Party.

I conclude by saying that I find it sad that we have here a piece of legislation which seeks retrospectively to legitimise an illegal act conducted by this Government for the purpose of ensuring its return to government. It does no credit to this Government that it finds itself in this situation, a situation it need not have been in.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I also will be brief, given the time of the day and day of the week. The last point raised is a good place to start. The Parliamentary Entitlements Bill 1990 does not do what Senator Crichton-Browne suggests it does. For decades successive governments have proceeded on the basis that they have the power within their capacity and the normal system of government, through appropriations legislation, to actually make services available to members of parliament. I say it has been going on for decades, because it has. It relates not purely to stamps, but to office accommodation in the electorate, parliamentary travel, travel overseas by delegations, spouse travel and even goes as far as the provision of Australian flags.

SPEECH.PARA: This Government and previous governments have all worked on the assumption, on the legal advice available to them, that they were able to make these benefits available to members and senators without the need for specific legislation. The High Court decision earlier this year basically turned around the premise on which governments in Australia have been working for decades. Let us get it in that context. There has been talk about grabbing money, hands in the till and allegations of illegal activity and being caught out by the High Court.

The reality is that the High Court found that the system under which governments, from Federation, have been operating has been wrongly based. The advice the Government has had after that High Court decision has been very firm, and that is we have to rectify it. What this legislation is doing is rectifying it, not solely for stamps but for every other benefit that has been available to members of parliament for which there is no specific legislative provision, or which has not been allocated by legislation through the mechanism of the Remuneration Tribunal. That is what this legislation does; and that is the full extent of it.

I am being a bit selective, and obviously, in politics one is not an orphan in doing that. People are being selective. We are talking about validation of what is called legitimate payments. Let us accept that all these services and benefits that members and senators have been receiving over the years have been received and used in the expectation that what every individual recipient has been doing has been within the law. Whether it has been the use of special purpose aircraft, electoral offices or stamps to communicate with their constituents, those benefits have been received by members of parliament, Ministers and office holders in good faith for decades.

The situation, in respect of stamps as well, is that the advice that was given to government-the advice that was available to the former Minister for Administrative Services, Stewart West-when the primary decision was taken was the same advice as had been received by previous governments of all political persuasions and that was that it was within the Government's capacity to do what was attempted to be done. The advice that came after the High Court decision, as is evidenced in documents that were tabled in the House of Representatives yesterday, was followed by the Minister. The advice that he gave to members of parliament after the High Court decision was received by him in good faith, and received in good faith by those who went off to use this benefit. Therefore, it is inconsistent to draw a political line between one benefit and another.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why didn't you give the same allowance to senators?
—Senator Crichton-Browne has said what he has to say. It was not new and I am sure what he is saying now by way of interjection is probably as stale and irrelevant as everything else.

SPEECH.PARA: The point I am making-I make this particularly for the Australian Democrats-is that it would be inconsistent to draw a line between those members of parliament who have used a particular service in good faith and others who have also used it in good faith. The people involved who have used it-from both sides of the Parliament-have used this particular facility in good faith, and the good faith extends to the decision making of government in this area as well.

I do not need to say much more, but I just repeat a point which has been made in this place and in the House of Representatives continually in the course of all the political grandstanding on this issue.

For the illumination of people who may be listening, let us go to the question of stamps. During 1989, the Government decided-part of the history has been related accurately-that it could make a determination on the appropriate level of postage entitlements for members of parliament. We have been presented this afternoon with a scenario of people lining up to put their hands in the till. We should look at this issue in an international context as well as a domestic context. For instance, in the United States of America members of lower Houses have a postage entitlement in order to send mail to their constituents five times per year. In Canada, it is three times per year. What was attempted in Australia was to allow members of the House of Representatives to communicate with their electorate once a year at Australia Post bulk-mail rates-a discounted rate-as opposed to what happens overseas. That is how the amount of $30,982 was arrived at.

In the domestic context, let me make just one point about inconsistency. I have sat with Senator Crichton-Browne at meetings of the Senate Standing Committee on Appropriations and Staffing at which he has stridently argued-if not in this place-for increased benefits for members and senators. The inconsistency I find now is that not only is Senator Crichton-Browne rejecting the $30,000 postage entitlement for members of the House of Representatives but also by his amendments he is actually taking the $9,600 which would otherwise have been available to senators back to $9,000. He is actually giving himself less. Let us take the issue out of the context of people running for the till. Basically, we are talking about a mechanism to communicate with one's constituents.

The Senate has to face two problems arising from the Opposition's amendments. The first is what to do with those people who have acted in good faith and have expended over $9,000. There are a number of them, on both sides of the Parliament, some of whom have lost their seats. The Australian Democrats are not affected. However, if the appropriate validating figure does not come in, the Democrats will be affected because not only are back bench entitlements and the Senate entitlement, which the High Court found to be non-existent, involved, but also the entitlements of leaders of parties are involved. What does one do with those people who have actually used this facility to communicate with their electorate?

Secondly, what do a whole range of members of parliament-probably almost half of the members of the House of Representatives-do for the next six weeks without a postage entitlement? Not only will those people suffer but also their electors will miss out on a very vital part of the democratic process-that is, the right to communication.

This Bill is not intended solely for the purpose of rectifying the situation arising from the Brown-West case in the High Court. It is basically to address the misapprehension that has been held by government. Based on legal advice from the Attorney-General's Department over decades, that the Parliament needs to enact specific legislation so that the facilities can be provided validly.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to give just a broad overview of comments on the Parliamentary Entitlements Bill in the committee stage itself. I would have thought that when the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) summed up, after all the remarks made both in this place and publicly, he would have had the decency to come out and say, `Look, we admit that what we did was not'-as he indicated-`to communicate with the electorate but was to provide additional funds at taxpayers' expense from the public purse to win an election'.
—Mr Chairman, I rise on a point of order. I hope Senator Parer will go to the amendment that he is moving and not embark on another second reading speech.

—Order! Senator Parer is not moving an amendment; he is discussing clauses 1 and 2 together, to which there are no amendments. Nevertheless, this should not be used as a rejoinder to a second reading conclusion speech. We are discussing clauses 1 and 2.

—I understand, Mr Chairman. I thought I would make those introductory remarks because I want to make some points before we get on to the main parts of the Bill. What I wish to address myself to has an effect on how we might consider some other points. We received the Bill, as the Minister will know, only a couple of days ago. I would like to ask the Minister a question which goes to the Bill. In clause 9.6 in the Remuneration Tribunal's determination of 1988 it was stated:

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I am having difficulty relating what you are saying to clauses 1 and 2. Perhaps you can link them into the title and the commencement date.

—It is important because it relates to the title and it would be interesting to get an explanation on some parts because they relate to the rest of the Bill.
